articles.headline: Visa Delays Put Iraqis Who Aided U.S. in Fear
articles.snippet: Terrorism fears in the United States are all but halting visas for Iraqis, even those who risked their lives aiding the war effort.
articles.abstract: Terrorism fears in the United States are all but halting visas for Iraqis, even those who risked their lives aiding the war effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Terrorism fears in the United States are all but halting visas for Iraqis, even those who risked their lives aiding the American war effort, making them especially vulnerable ahead of the planned American military withdrawal.

articles.headline: E.U. Vows to Back Banks That Fail Stress Tests
articles.snippet: As Moody’s cut Ireland’s credit rating to junk status, European Union ministers voiced support for weak banks but left unresolved deep disputes that have held up a second rescue package for Greece.
articles.abstract: As Moody’s cut Ireland’s credit rating to junk status, European Union ministers voiced support for weak banks but left unresolved deep disputes that have held up a second rescue package for Greece.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European officials vowed on Tuesday to support banks that fail stress tests but left unresolved deep disputes that have held up a second rescue package for Greece.

articles.headline: Family Differences, Global Issues
articles.snippet: Recent Greek history is in many ways defined — for better or for worse — by three generations of Papandreou prime ministers.
articles.abstract: Recent Greek history is in many ways defined — for better or for worse — by three generations of Papandreou prime ministers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In a sun-drenched room at the foundation here that is named for his father, Nick Papandreou pondered the task confronting his older brother, George: dismantling the Greek welfare state largely erected by their father, Andreas Papandreou.

articles.headline: Why Taxes Will Rise in the End
articles.snippet: Economists have a name for a budget that covers soaring medical costs and pays for the world’s largest military with some of the world’s lowest taxes: a free lunch.
articles.abstract: Economists have a name for a budget that covers soaring medical costs and pays for the world’s largest military with some of the world’s lowest taxes: a free lunch.

articles.headline: Netflix Raises Price of DVD and Online Movies Package by 60%
articles.snippet: Netflix advertised the change as a new choice for consumers, but thousands of the company’s customers complained online.
articles.abstract: Netflix advertised the change as a new choice for consumers, but thousands of the company’s customers complained online.
articles.lead_paragraph: DVDs are not dead yet, but they are going to cost more — at least for customers of Netflix, the popular entertainment service, which said on Tuesday that it was sharply increasing the price of its Internet-plus-DVDs-in-the-mail plan.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Sam Grobart

articles.headline: Bank of America’s Mortgage Deal Questioned
articles.snippet: The New York attorney general asked for information about the $8.5 billion settlement agreed to by Bank of America and investment firms holding soured mortgage securities.
articles.abstract: The New York attorney general asked for information about the $8.5 billion settlement agreed to by Bank of America and investment firms holding soured mortgage securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eric Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, has asked for information about the $8.5 billion settlement agreed to late last month by Bank of America and representatives of 22 large investment firms holding soured mortgage securities, indicating that he may intervene to challenge the deal.

articles.headline: Revolution Dims Star Power of Egypt’s Antiquities Chief
articles.snippet: Egypt’s minister of antiquities, Zahi Hawass, was a symbol of national pride until the upheaval in his country drew scrutiny into his relationship with the Mubarak family.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s minister of antiquities, Zahi Hawass, was a symbol of national pride until the upheaval in his country drew scrutiny into his relationship with the Mubarak family.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until recently Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s antiquities minister, was a global symbol of Egyptian national pride. A famous archaeologist in an Indiana Jones hat, he was virtually unassailable in the old Egypt, protected by his success in boosting tourism, his efforts to reclaim lost artifacts and his closeness to the country’s first lady, Suzanne Mubarak.

articles.headline: To Rebound, RIM Courts the Carriers
articles.snippet: With many wireless carriers feeling threatened by the growing prominence of Apple and Google, those companies’ success could provide the foundation of Research in Motion’s recovery.
articles.abstract: With many wireless carriers feeling threatened by the growing prominence of Apple and Google, those companies’ success could provide the foundation of Research in Motion’s recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Even though Research in Motion, the maker of BlackBerry devices, has been undermined by Apple’s iPhone and phones using Google’s Android software, the exceptional success of its competitors could provide the foundation of its recovery.

articles.headline: Debt Talk Mired, Leader for G.O.P. Proposes Option
articles.snippet: Pessimism spread about the prospects of a debt-limit deal, prompting the Senate Republican leader to give a “last-choice option.”
articles.abstract: Pessimism spread about the prospects of a debt-limit deal, prompting the Senate Republican leader to give a “last-choice option.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the White House and Congress to financial centers, pessimism spread on Tuesday about the prospects of a debt-limit deal between President Obama and Republicans, prompting the Senate Republican leader to propose a “last-choice option” that piqued the administration’s interest but angered conservatives in his own party.

articles.headline: Connections to Murdoch Start to Chafe British Leader
articles.snippet: Prime Minister David Cameron has found himself a step behind in reacting to the phone-hacking revelations and his own associations with the press.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron has found himself a step behind in reacting to the phone-hacking revelations and his own associations with the press.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron is usually the nimblest of politicians, radiating self-assurance and blessed with an almost Reaganesque ability to deflect criticism. But as the phone hacking scandal spreads, Mr. Cameron has been placed in the unaccustomed position of appearing vulnerable and behind the curve.
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Bernanke Says Fed Would Consider New Stimulus
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke said that the Federal Reserve was reconsidering its decision to refrain from new measures.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke said that the Federal Reserve was reconsidering its decision to refrain from new measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, gave a subdued account of the economy’s health Wednesday and said that the Fed was prepared to expand its economic aid campaign once again, if necessary, though such a step was not imminent.
